title: Grazing halos on coral reefs: predation risk, herbivore density, and habitat size influence grazing patterns that are visible from space
authors: DiFiore, Bp; Queenborough, Sa; Madin, Emp; Paul, Vj; Decker, Mb; Stier, Ac

analysis.summary: This review paper explores how the International Long-Term Ecological Research Network (ILTER), with more than 100 coastal and marine research sites worldwide, could serve as a platform for global ocean observation to address challenges like climate change and biodiversity loss.
analysis.keyQuestion: How can the coastal and marine components of ILTER contribute to integrated global observation of biological and ecological aspects of coastal ecosystems?
analysis.approach: The researchers conducted a SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats) analysis of ILTER's coastal and marine sites, examined how their data fits with Essential Ocean Variables framework, and reviewed the network's organizational structure and capabilities.
keyFindings: ILTER includes more than 100 coastal and marine sites across 44 countries with systematic coverage of marine environments
While most coastal and marine sites were established after 2000, some date back to the early 1900s
The network measures a broad variety of abiotic and biotic variables that could feed into global ocean observing initiatives
ILTER sites are committed to free and open data sharing following FAIR principles for data management
analysis.stickyFact: Some ILTER coastal and marine observation sites have been collecting data since the early 1900s, providing historical depth that newer monitoring programs cannot match.
analysis.whyItMatters: This research identifies how existing long-term ecological research sites could be better integrated into global ocean observation systems, providing crucial biological and ecological data needed to understand and manage threats from climate change, overfishing, and other human impacts on marine ecosystems.
analysis.species: Not species-specific; focuses on marine ecosystems broadly
analysis.newsHeadline: Century-Old Ocean Research Sites Could Transform Global Marine Monitoring
analysis.essay:
When we began mapping the coastal and marine components of the International Long-Term Ecological Research Network, we discovered something remarkable: while most of these sites were established after 2000, some have been quietly collecting data since the early 1900s. Working with my colleagues Nicholas Nidzieko, Alicia Acosta, and dozens of other researchers across the globe, we found ourselves sitting on a treasure trove of marine observations that could revolutionize how we monitor our changing oceans.

We wanted to answer a pressing question: how could these more than 100 coastal and marine ILTER sites, scattered across 44 countries, contribute to global ocean observation? The challenge was understanding whether this network of individual research sites, each with their own history and methods, could work together as a coordinated observing system. We conducted what's called a SWOT analysis—examining the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of using ILTER as a platform for global marine monitoring.

What we discovered was a network with remarkable reach and longevity. These sites span the globe, providing systematic coverage of terrestrial, freshwater, and marine environments. Some sites date back to the early 1900s, giving ILTER a unique ability to document long-term environmental change that satellite data and newer monitoring programs simply cannot match.

What surprised us most was how fragmented this wealth of data remains. While ILTER sites are committed to free and open data sharing following FAIR principles, actually putting these principles into practice is still challenging at most sites. The network has tools to standardize metadata, but coordination between sites remains limited. We found that many sites collect similar variables but use different methods, making comparisons difficult.

This matters because understanding threats to marine biodiversity and ecosystem services requires exactly the kind of integrated, long-term biological observations that ILTER sites provide. Physical and chemical ocean monitoring is already well-established through networks like the Global Ocean Observing System, but biological and ecological observations lag far behind. ILTER sites measure the broad variety of biological variables needed to understand how marine ecosystems respond to climate change, overfishing, and pollution.

The big question moving forward is whether we can transform this collection of individual research sites into a truly coordinated global observing system. We need better standardization of methods, improved data sharing infrastructure, and stronger connections between ILTER and existing ocean observing networks. The potential is enormous—imagine having decades of biological data from coastal sites worldwide, all accessible and comparable. But realizing that potential will require overcoming decades of independent operation and building new collaborative frameworks.
